user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetID:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetID(void)
{
    int32 IdBuf;

    /* always delegate to low-level API */
    if (OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(&IdBuf) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return a hardcoded value on failure */
        return -1;
    }

    return IdBuf;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int32 IdBuf;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment only declares an int32 variable and does not call any <string.h> functions nor use character-buffer pointers. The declaration itself cannot cause out-of-bounds string accesses. (A possible violation would occur if the address of IdBuf were passed to a string function that writes more bytes than sizeof(IdBuf) — e.g. passing (char *)&IdBuf to strcpy/memcpy with a length exceeding sizeof(IdBuf)).
